issue.title: date_sub() inconsistency with timestamps and 'week'
issue.body:
### What happens?

Came across this working on the tests for Malloy's interval measurement.

If I use `date_sub()` to measure an interval one second shorter than a week, it returns zero weeks. If I use it to measure an interval one second shorter than a year, it returns 52 weeks. I expected it to return 51. Time is complicated and maybe my expectation is wrong?

### To Reproduce

```SQL
SELECT
  DATE_SUB('week', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-01 12:00:00', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-08 12:00:00') as oneWeek,
  DATE_SUB('week', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-01 12:00:00', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-08 11:59:59') as almostWeek,
  DATE_SUB('week', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-01 12:00:00', TIMESTAMP '2002-01-01 12:00:00') as yearWeeks,
  DATE_SUB('week', TIMESTAMP '2001-01-01 12:00:00', TIMESTAMP '2002-01-01 11:59:59') as almostYear
  ```
 
  
  ```
  â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ oneWeek â”‚ almostWeek â”‚ yearWeeks â”‚ almostYear â”‚
â”‚  int64  â”‚   int64    â”‚   int64   â”‚   int64    â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚       1 â”‚          0 â”‚        52 â”‚         52 â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

issue.title: duckdb.connect is adding the working directory
issue.body:
### What happens?

I am using duckdb 0.71 on python in windows 11 using VS Code

My script is:

import duckdb

directory = "E:/rapid7/"
db = "domain2.ddb"

con = duckdb.connect(directory + db)

I am getting the following error:

duckdb.IOException: IO Error: Cannot open file "C:\Code\E:/rapid7/domain2.ddb": The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect.

My working directory in VS code is C:\Code.  Based on the above code I would expect E:/rapid7/domain2.ddb and would not expect duckdb to add C:\Code

### To Reproduce

See code above

### OS:

Windows 11 x64

### DuckDB Version:

0.71

### DuckDB Client:

python 10.8

### Full Name:

Peter Chaplin

### Affiliation:

ESB Connect ltd

### Have you tried this on the latest `master` branch?

- [X] I agree

### Have you tried the steps to reproduce? Do they include all relevant data and configuration? Does the issue you report still appear there?

- [X] I agree

comment.body:
Thanks for raising the issue :)

I believe the issue here is that your path separator isn't correct, so we don't recognize this as an absolute path on Windows.
Also we've taken a stab at fixing this in the past, but Windows is always tricky <https://github.com/duckdb/duckdb/pull/5852>

pull_request.title: add support for scaning over numpy arrays
pull_request.body:
Support for scanning over numpy arrays.

Three types of Numpy-related parameter are accepted:

- Dict[str (name), array] - use the keys of the dict to set the column names
- List[array] - use default names (column0, column1, etc..)
- array - same as List

To support scanning over numpy arrays, code for scanning pandas dataframes is reused.

pull_request.title: Fixes #6775 Invariants scalar function
pull_request.body:
This PR adds the Assert/Invariant function as discussed in the #6775.

assert function accepts two arguments, such as `input` and the `condition`. If the condition evaluates to `NULL` or `true`, it returns the input argument, if the condition evaluates to `false`, it throws an invalid input exception.

The `input` argument can be any type. The `condition` argument should evaluate to a boolean.
 

Example for a failed assertion:
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 5 AS denom
    UNION ALL
    SELECT 0 AS denom
  )
)

Invalid Input Error: Assertion failed for assert(denom, (denom != 0))
```

Example for a verified assertion
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT denom.assert(denom != 0) as denom
  // OR assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 1 AS denom
  )
)
----
42
```

Note: Please let me know if I missed any details, to be able to support the any type, I could not use the existing utility functions.

commits.message: LIST aggregate - remove type from aggregate state
LIST finalize - read directly into result vector instead of reading into an intermediate vector and then appending
List - inline first LinkedList entry instead of allocating, and turn LinkedList into references instead of pointers
Split allocation size from allocation in ListSegment allocate
Clean-up - unify all ListSegment functions into a single class
Push AggregateInputInfo into aggregate destructors as well
LIST - remove usage of AllocatedData, and instead use Allocator passed in in destructor to de-allocate
List aggregate - actually grow list segments
Add RowOperationsState, and push allocator into actual hash tables instead
List aggregate - move to using arena allocators stored in the aggregate/perfect aggregate HT
AggregateObject - hold shared copy of FunctionData of aggregates to simplify memory management of aggregate hash tables
Revert aggregate parallel threshold, and add missing include

Merge pull request #6995 from Mytherin/listimprovements

LIST aggregate performance improvements

pull_request.title: LIST aggregate performance improvements
pull_request.body:
This PR improves the performance of the `LIST` aggregate in several ways:

* Use an `ArenaAllocator` that is stored in the aggregate/perfect hash table to do the allocation of the list segments
* Avoid storing the `AllocatedData` in a vector in the aggregate state of the list - instead use the provided allocator in the destructor to de-allocate the segments
* Avoid allocating the root `LinkedList` and instead store this as part of the hash table
* Avoid storing the `LogicalType` in the aggregate state of the list - instead use the type from the bind data

This results in many fewer allocations made, particularly when there are many small lists. They also improve data locality as a result of using large heaps for the allocations. Here are some performance numbers for the two included benchmarks:

|              Benchmark               |  Old  |  New  |
|--------------------------------------|-------|-------|
| Many Small Lists (150K lists, 1-7 rows per list)   | 3.5s  | 0.06s |
| Few Large Lists (3 lists, 140K - 300K rows per list) | 0.03s | 0.02s |

These changes require a few modifications to the aggregate hash tables and row layout, particularly to pass in the allocator from the hash table to the actual hash function:

* The destroy function now also takes an `AggregateFunctionInput`
* The `RowOperations` methods take a `RowOperationsState`, which contains an Allocator
* The `AggregateHashTable` and `PerfectAggregateHashTable` are extended with an `ArenaAllocator` object

For the scan of the `PhysicalHashAggregate` we also launch multiple threads sooner - instead of only launching one thread per row group size we launch one thread per vector. Hash tables are scanned per-vector, and multiple threads processing the output of a hash table becomes beneficial already with low row counts when lists are involved.

issue.title: `httpfs` extension doesn't work on musl libc systems like Alpine.
issue.body:
### What happens?

It appears that the extension `httpfs` doesn't support [musl](https://musl.libc.org) based systems like [Alpine](https://alpinelinux.org).

```
duckdb.IOException: IO Error: Extension "/root/.duckdb/extensions/v0.7.1/linux_arm64/httpfs.duckdb_extension" could not be loaded: Error loading shared library ld-linux-aarch64.so.1: No such file or directory (needed by /root/.duckdb/extensions/v0.7.1/linux_arm64/httpfs.duckdb_extension)
```


### To Reproduce

Dockerfile:
```
FROM python:3.11-alpine

RUN apk add build-base 
RUN pip install duckdb
```

Build that: `docker build -t duck_test:latest .`

Run it: `docker run --rm -it duck_test:latest`

In that shell, now do:
```python
>>> import duckdb
>>> con = duckdb.connect(':memory:')
>>> con.install_extension('httpfs')
>>> con.load_extension('httpfs')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
duckdb.IOException: IO Error: Extension "/root/.duckdb/extensions/v0.7.1/linux_arm64/httpfs.duckdb_extension" could not be loaded: Error loading shared library ld-linux-aarch64.so.1: No such file or directory (needed by /root/.duckdb/extensions/v0.7.1/linux_arm64/httpfs.duckdb_extension)
>>> 
```

I tried with `RUN pip install duckdb --upgrade --pre` and got the same results.

Using a Debian or Ubuntu base image loading the extension works as expected.


### OS:

Alpine Linux (both aarch64 and x64)

### DuckDB Version:

0.7.1

### DuckDB Client:

Python

### Full Name:

michael conrad tadpol tilstra

### Affiliation:

Exosite

### Have you tried this on the latest `master` branch?

- [X] I agree

### Have you tried the steps to reproduce? Do they include all relevant data and configuration? Does the issue you report still appear there?

- [X] I agree

In the [BigQuery example](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/standard-sql/debugging_functions) they avoid the optimizer by either using the function in the `WHERE` clause with an `IF` condition, or by using it in a `CASE` statement. I think that is fine as a work-around - it just seems more readable to me.

> value.assert(x -> x != 0)

The issue with this syntax is that it is very geared towards this one case (checking for 0 on a single variable) - it would not work in general if you have more complex conditions you want to check. I also think the `ERROR` function has potential other purposes as a debug function because it can be used to e.g. test correct error handling in clients.
`DefaultCast` here means that extension types will not be correctly converted to string - if we could change this to a `VectorOperations::Cast` instead we can convert those correctly.

issue.title: Fixes #6775 Invariants scalar function
issue.body:
This PR adds the Assert/Invariant function as discussed in the #6775.

assert function accepts two arguments, such as `input` and the `condition`. If the condition evaluates to `NULL` or `true`, it returns the input argument, if the condition evaluates to `false`, it throws an invalid input exception.

The `input` argument can be any type. The `condition` argument should evaluate to a boolean.
 

Example for a failed assertion:
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 5 AS denom
    UNION ALL
    SELECT 0 AS denom
  )
)

Invalid Input Error: Assertion failed for assert(denom, (denom != 0))
```

Example for a verified assertion
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT denom.assert(denom != 0) as denom
  // OR assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 1 AS denom
  )
)
----
42
```

Note: Please let me know if I missed any details, to be able to support the any type, I could not use the existing utility functions.

comment.body:
Ah my bad for suggesting it then.

Though I think the reasoning was that if the result is unused, it could get optimized out.

That is what inspired the `value.assert(x -> x != 0)` idea

comment.body:
> Thanks for the PR! So the core idea here is that multiple ordered aggregates are finalized/ordered at once, correct?
> 
> Is there a possibility that this will degrade performance in case the inputs are larger? For example, if we have 1000 rows per aggregate, we would now be sorting 2 million rows at once, instead of 1000 rows 2048 times. I imagine there is some threshold where this batching no longer has a positive impact.
> 
> Perhaps you could run some benchmarks, and adaptively figure out whether or not to combine states before sorting?

Yes that's a good point. Basically a mix of the two. Pull out the sizes without sinking into the `LocalSortState` and then switch based on some threshold.  The state should be tracking the size anyway for the eventual linked list integration.

issue.title: Add json->sql deserialisation and execution.
issue.body:
This is a continuation of #6647 and  adds three new functions:
- `json_deserialize_sql(JSON)`: convert a json serialized sql select statement back into an (equivalent) sql statement string.
- `json_execute_serialized_sql(JSON)`: execute a json serialized sql select statement directly as a table function - basically as if it were a subquery.
- `PRAGMA json_execute_serialized_sql(VARCHAR)`: execute a json serialized sql select statement as if it were a top level statement through a pragma instead. Basically deserialises the given json back into a sql string which is then executed normally.

I have tested this by hacking in a json ser/de roundtrip in the DeserializedStatementVerifier, and it passes the entire duckdb unit test suite, so I am reasonably confident that this implementation is correct and serializes e.g. all the types, expressions and values correctly, but I will add a proper deserialization/serialization verification pass when I add the binary FormatDe/Serializer in core duckdb.

comment.body: Thanks! LGTM. Next up replacing the existing (de)serialize methods nad unifying all the (de)serialize infrastructure :)

issue.title: [Safety] Add safety checks to `vector` indexing
issue.body:
This PR is less massive ;)

The only thing that needed to be done was remove explicit use of `std::vector`, and luckily we already had `duckdb/common/vector.hpp` to introduce `vector` into the duckdb namespace.

Same as the `unique_ptr`, this will likely be a two-phase PR. The first phase is moving away from `std::vector` to our class (which is derived from std::vector), and the next phase will be to introduce the safety check.

The safety check will likely incur some performance issues where vectors are being indexed heavily, and will require some profiling to figure out where this happens.
That's the main reason for doing this in two phases

pull_request.title: Fixes #6775 Invariants scalar function
pull_request.body:
This PR adds the Assert/Invariant function as discussed in the #6775.

assert function accepts two arguments, such as `input` and the `condition`. If the condition evaluates to `NULL` or `true`, it returns the input argument, if the condition evaluates to `false`, it throws an invalid input exception.

The `input` argument can be any type. The `condition` argument should evaluate to a boolean.
 

Example for a failed assertion:
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 5 AS denom
    UNION ALL
    SELECT 0 AS denom
  )
)

Invalid Input Error: Assertion failed for assert(denom, (denom != 0))
```

Example for a verified assertion
```
SELECT 42 / denom
FROM (
  SELECT denom.assert(denom != 0) as denom
  // OR assert(denom, denom != 0) as denom
  FROM (
    SELECT 1 AS denom
  )
)
----
42
```

Note: Please let me know if I missed any details, to be able to support the any type, I could not use the existing utility functions.

pull_request.title: LIST aggregate performance improvements
pull_request.body:
This PR improves the performance of the `LIST` aggregate in several ways:

* Use an `ArenaAllocator` that is stored in the aggregate/perfect hash table to do the allocation of the list segments
* Avoid storing the `AllocatedData` in a vector in the aggregate state of the list - instead use the provided allocator in the destructor to de-allocate the segments
* Avoid allocating the root `LinkedList` and instead store this as part of the hash table
* Avoid storing the `LogicalType` in the aggregate state of the list - instead use the type from the bind data

This results in many fewer allocations made, particularly when there are many small lists. They also improve data locality as a result of using large heaps for the allocations. Here are some performance numbers for the two included benchmarks:

|              Benchmark               |  Old  |  New  |
|--------------------------------------|-------|-------|
| Many Small Lists (150K lists, 1-7 rows per list)   | 3.5s  | 0.06s |
| Few Large Lists (3 lists, 140K - 300K rows per list) | 0.03s | 0.02s |

These changes require a few modifications to the aggregate hash tables and row layout, particularly to pass in the allocator from the hash table to the actual hash function:

* The destroy function now also takes an `AggregateFunctionInput`
* The `RowOperations` methods take a `RowOperationsState`, which contains an Allocator
* The `AggregateHashTable` and `PerfectAggregateHashTable` are extended with an `ArenaAllocator` object

For the scan of the `PhysicalHashAggregate` we also launch multiple threads sooner - instead of only launching one thread per row group size we launch one thread per vector. Hash tables are scanned per-vector, and multiple threads processing the output of a hash table becomes beneficial already with low row counts when lists are involved.

issue.title: [Safety] Add safety checks to `vector` indexing
issue.body:
This PR is less massive ;)

The only thing that needed to be done was remove explicit use of `std::vector`, and luckily we already had `duckdb/common/vector.hpp` to introduce `vector` into the duckdb namespace.

Same as the `unique_ptr`, this will likely be a two-phase PR. The first phase is moving away from `std::vector` to our class (which is derived from std::vector), and the next phase will be to introduce the safety check.

The safety check will likely incur some performance issues where vectors are being indexed heavily, and will require some profiling to figure out where this happens.
That's the main reason for doing this in two phases

comment.body:

comment.body: Yes, I did a slight rework in the perfect aggregate HT by essentially calling the `initialize` for all groups up-front instead of lazily while adding chunks. The reason I did that was that the code previously relied on using `memcpy` in the combine phase if the aggregate was set in one of the hash tables, but not in the other hash table. This caused problems with the new arena allocator since it would copy over the pointers to the arena allocator of the old hash table instead of moving the data to the new hash table, and would then cause use-after-free later. In the new setup, we can just always call combine since there is always a correctly initialized empty state in each bucket.

These changes require a few modifications to the aggregate hash tables and row layout, particularly to pass in the allocator from the hash table to the actual hash function:

* The destroy function now also takes an `AggregateFunctionInput`
* The `RowOperations` methods take a `RowOperationsState`, which contains an Allocator
* The `AggregateHashTable` and `PerfectAggregateHashTable` are extended with an `ArenaAllocator` object

For the scan of the `PhysicalHashAggregate` we also launch multiple threads sooner - instead of only launching one thread per row group size we launch one thread per vector. Hash tables are scanned per-vector, and multiple threads processing the output of a hash table becomes beneficial already with low row counts when lists are involved.

pull_request.title: Tuple Data Collection
pull_request.body:
This PR implements `TupleDataCollection`, an (even) more unified way of materializing data in row format.

In various places in DuckDB's execution engine, we materialize data in row format using `RowDataCollection` and `RowLayout`. While this is already a somewhat unified way of materializing data in row format, it has a few issues when we want to spill the row data to disk. The pointers within the row format have to be manually (un)swizzled when (un)pinned. This is cumbersome and requires some serious bookkeeping within physical operators that use row format data. This (un)swizzling may also be redundant if the blocks that hold the data are never written to disk, which may happen in cases where the data size is only slightly over the memory limit.

This PR implements the `TupleDataCollection` class that, similar to the `ColumnDataCollection` class (#4315), `DataChunk`s can simply be appended or scanned, without the need to explicitly hold buffer pins in various places in the code. This is all managed by the `TupleDataAllocator` class. The two problems described above (regarding pointer swizzling) are addressed in a similar way to how pointers in a `ColumnDataCollection` are never explicitly swizzled (#5543). In short, we simply compare pointers to see whether the block was spilled to disk. If the pointers are different, we recompute them, if the pointers are the same, they are still valid and nothing needs to be done.

`TupleDataCollection` has been integrated in `JoinHashTable` and `AggregateHashTable`, and should be integrated into the sorting code before the old `RowDataCollection` can be phased out. At that point I would like to rename `TupleDataCollection` to `RowDataCollection` for more consistency with naming in the code base.

This PR also brings improvements to the out-of-core hash join, and should improve the out-of-core capabilities of the hash aggregate. To improve the out-of-core hash join, I've implemented `PartitionedTupleData`, which, similar to `PartitionedColumnData` (#4970), we can append `DataChunk`s to, directly to the partitions. Rather than materializing all data in a single `TupleDataCollection`, we now immediately materialize to 16 partitions. If all data fits in memory, we combine the partitions into one, and perform an in-memory hash join. If not all data fits in memory, we combine as many partitions as fit in memory into one, and do a partitioned hash join like before. If a single one of the 16 partitions does not fit in memory, we repartition to up to 256 partitions, and perform the out-of-core hash join like before.

I've ran the same benchmark as in the previous PRs (linked above):

| Memory limit (GB) | Old time (s) | New time (s) |
|-------------------|--------------|--------------|
| 10                | 1.74         | 1.56         |
| 5                 | 2.47         | 2.09         |
| 3                 | 4.54         | 3.64         |
| 1                 | 4.80         | 3.66         |

I got a bit side-tracked in this PR and vectorized some code in `hive_partitioning.cpp` and was able to improve the runtime of `to_parquet_partition_by_many.benchmark` from ~2.95s to ~2.25s on my laptop.

P.S.: I am definitely not done tweaking the performance of the hash join/aggregate, especially after speaking with Thomas Neumann here at ICDE. I look forward to optimizing these operators more in the future.

Also, this definitely has merge conflicts with #6995. Happy to fix them and merge this after that has been merged.

issue.title: Add basic support for GeoSpatial type
issue.body:
Hi DuckDB team,

I would like to implement the GeoSpatial data type in DuckDB. This will require quite a bit of work, so I propose breaking it up into two parts. The first part will be implementing the following, which will not be a â€˜complete featureâ€™ but I think would be good to get some feedback on making sure I am along the right path with the implementation. Here is how I would break it down:
**Part 1** (partial implementation)
- [ ] Support for the `POINT` geospatial object.
- [ ] Support for one Constructor function, `ST_MAKEPOINT`.
- [ ] Support for one Input function, `ST_GEOGFROM`.
- [ ] Support for one Output function, `ST_ASTEXT`.
- [ ] Support for one Accessor function, `ST_X`.
- [ ] Support for one Calculation/main function, `ST_DISTANCE`.
- [ ] Support for one Transformation function, `ST_CENTROID`. (Note: this will return itself for a point, so for the time being it will be trivial).

Once I complete this I will discuss what Iâ€™ll work on for Part 2, but it will be adding basic support for the main geospatial objects, such as `LineString`, `Polygon`, `MultiPoint`, `MultiLineString`, `MultiPolygon`, and `GeometryCollection`, and adding some of the most common functions for each of the six function types, and provide suggestions for future improvements if someone want to continue on the work (such as adding in indexes or more functions).
I will be using PostGIS and MySQL for references on open source implementations, though I think PostGIS is the standard here and since it works so well with Postgres, I will probably use that primarily for reference and copying over some of the main components.
@Mytherin -- could you please review the above and let me know your thoughts on this?

comment.body:
> @Maxxen For the licensing part @Mytherin said we could use an extension with GPL license [#2836 (comment)](https://github.com/duckdb/duckdb/issues/2836#issuecomment-1001706148). I really want a clarification from the duckdb team maybe the context changed since.

While extensions can certainly have the GPL license (as the geo extension by @handstuyennn does), the GPL license invokes certain limitations that inhibit the extension from being used in several configurations where people would otherwise be able to use DuckDB.

This is more relevant to DuckDB than for a traditional database like Postgres. For Postgres, the database server operates as a separate application that the user uses a client library (psql) to talk to. For DuckDB, the user generally links to DuckDB directly and uses it as a library. This linking part is what is problematic - since GPL specifies that any applications [that links to GPL also need to be licensed as GPL.](https://opensource.org/license/gpl-2-0/).

> This General Public License does not permit incorporating your program into proprietary programs. If your program is a subroutine library, you may consider it more useful to permit linking proprietary applications with the library. If this is what you want to do, use the GNU Library General Public License instead of this License.

This essentially prohibits people from creating an application that uses DuckDB with a GPL licensed extension incorporated, without also licensing their code as GPL. This same limitation would not apply to people using Postgres with the PostGIS library, since only the client library (`psql`) is linked to, which is not GPL licensed.

This is not relevant for people using the extension from within scripts like Python, so this does not prohibit all usages of the extension, and of course is totally fine if you are willing to license your own code as GPL. However, the license could prove to be problematic for people that want to build software on top of DuckDB with the extension, such that we would prefer to avoid these problems for the extensions that we actively support.

> As an user, I don't want to have 2 extensions in this field. GeoSpacial is hard enough and I don't want to think on what extension I have to use.

Yes, it is unfortunate that there are now two extensions from a user perspective. The reason there are two extensions is that they prioritize different goals, as has been discussed earlier [here](https://github.com/duckdb/duckdb/pull/5026#issuecomment-1283690932). The geo extension is heavily based on PostGIS code, and essentially enables the usage of PostGIS within DuckDB, which is awesome and very useful. It is, however, limited to being as good as PostGIS, as it is not tightly integrated with all of DuckDB's native capabilities.

The spatial extension instead has put a lot of work on making geospatial functionality natively integrated with DuckDB's internals, so it can operate more efficiently, with DuckDB's execution, data representation and memory management model in mind. Due to this, the spatial extension has the potential to become more powerful and efficient than PostGIS, but development also takes significantly longer as there is a lot more functionality to implement.

The Spatial extension also already provides additional features that PostGIS does not, such as the GDAL and PROJ integrations, and has put a lot of effort into packaging them in a portable way, so that it can be used in all contexts where DuckDB is used, including in e.g. the WASM builds.

We are definitely open to unifying the two extensions, and are aiming for the spatial extension to cover all of the functionality that you could expect from a GIS module. Unfortunately, we cannot just copy over the code from the geo extension due to licensing constraints. We would of course be happy to integrate the code and tests that @handstuyennn wrote themselves with their permission and work together on achieving a single awesome geospatial extension for DuckDB.

issue.title: [Safety] Add safety checks to `vector` indexing
issue.body:
This PR is less massive ;)

The only thing that needed to be done was remove explicit use of `std::vector`, and luckily we already had `duckdb/common/vector.hpp` to introduce `vector` into the duckdb namespace.

Same as the `unique_ptr`, this will likely be a two-phase PR. The first phase is moving away from `std::vector` to our class (which is derived from std::vector), and the next phase will be to introduce the safety check.

The safety check will likely incur some performance issues where vectors are being indexed heavily, and will require some profiling to figure out where this happens.
That's the main reason for doing this in two phases

comment.body:
I think it makes sense to have the changes to duckdb-wasm hash here, since they are connected. Looks good.

Also worth writing down somewhere that currently duck-wasm hash is used only for testing changes in duckdb, and no one is relying on generated build artifacts, so there are no visible consequences, only ducdkb developers will see potentially different test results (but that's true with any PR...).

This is to say, it make sense they are tied, and also avoid an extra CI round for no reason.

commits.message:
Issue #6881: Window Memory Segfault

The problem was we were not pinning blocks when scattering them to rows prior to sorting.
Also fixed a problem where forcing inlined strings would crash the unswizzling code
because the scatter code was writing null strings with length 1.

Merge pull request #6984 from hawkfish/window-memory

Issue #6881: Window Memory Segfault

pull_request.title: Issue #6881: Window Memory Segfault
pull_request.body:
The problem was we were not pinning blocks when scattering them to rows prior to sorting. 
Also fixed a problem where forcing inlined strings would crash the unswizzling code because the scatter code was writing null strings with length 1.

issue.title: Reading parquet file causes a segfault
issue.body:
### What happens?

I installed duckdb 0.71 and tried to read a parquet file which lead to a segfault that I cannot troubleshoot/debug.


### To Reproduce

The issue can be reproduced with the following steps. The parquet file is attached as well.

```
$ duckdb                                         
v0.7.1 b00b93f0b1
Enter ".help" for usage hints.
Connected to a transient in-memory database.
Use ".open FILENAME" to reopen on a persistent database.
D select count(*) FROM read_parquet('out/data.parquet');
zsh: segmentation fault  duckdb
```

Parquet file: [data.parquet.zip](https://github.com/duckdb/duckdb/files/11170831/data.parquet.zip).


### OS:

OS X, Apple M1 Pro

### DuckDB Version:

0.7.1

### DuckDB Client:

CLI

### Full Name:

Filip Petkovski

### Affiliation:

Shopify

### Have you tried this on the latest `master` branch?

- [X] I agree

### Have you tried the steps to reproduce? Do they include all relevant data and configuration? Does the issue you report still appear there?

- [X] I agree

issue.title: [Safety] Add safety checks to `vector` indexing
issue.body:
This PR is less massive ;)

The only thing that needed to be done was remove explicit use of `std::vector`, and luckily we already had `duckdb/common/vector.hpp` to introduce `vector` into the duckdb namespace.

Same as the `unique_ptr`, this will likely be a two-phase PR. The first phase is moving away from `std::vector` to our class (which is derived from std::vector), and the next phase will be to introduce the safety check.

The safety check will likely incur some performance issues where vectors are being indexed heavily, and will require some profiling to figure out where this happens.
That's the main reason for doing this in two phases
